review.title: Change in Abstract Argumentation Frameworks: Adding an Argument
review.abstract: In this paper, we address the problem of change in an abstract argumentation system. We focus on a particular change: the addition of a new argument which interacts with previous arguments. We study the impact of such an addition on the outcome of the argumentation system, more particularly on the set of its extensions. Several properties for this change operation are defined by comparing the new set of extensions to the initial one, these properties are called structural when the comparisons are based on set-cardinality or set-inclusion relations. Several other properties are proposed where comparisons are based on the status of some particular arguments: the accepted arguments; these properties refer to the evolution of this status during the change, e.g., Monotony and Priority to Recency. All these properties may be more or less desirable according to specific applications. They are studied under two particular semantics: the grounded and preferred semantics.

sections.heading: 3. Change in Argumentation
sections.text: We introduce a formal definition of the change in the reasoning, which makes it possible to distinguish between four types of changes. Then, we define properties for a change in the reasoning. First, we consider the effects of a change on the structure of a series of extensions and examine how this structure is modified. This point of view leads to the definition of structural properties. Then, we consider the effects of a change on the set of arguments that are accepted. Finally, the connections between the two classes of properties are studied. Note that the definition for most of the properties we present is general in the sense that it can be applied to any kind of change. In Section 4 (where we specify conditions for satisfying these properties), we will focus on the specific case of adding an argument and its interactions.

sections.text: The structural properties presented in this section are based on the effects of the change on the structure of the set of extensions. Note that the definition for each property is general in the sense that the nature of the modification is not specified: it may consist of adding an interaction, removing an interaction, adding an argument and a series of interactions related to that argument, or removing an argument. However, for clarity reasons, each property in this section is presented with examples of the modification process. sections.heading: 3.3 Status-Based Properties
sections.text: In this section, we are interested in the effects of a modification operation on the status of certain arguments. • First, we are interested in the status of the arguments that were accepted before a change, resulting in a property called "monotony" that can be defined for any kind of change. • Another interesting topic concerns the status of the argument that is added when a change is made. Obviously, it only affects the modification operation, and this results in a property called "priority over novelty," which only makes sense for one type of change.

sections.heading: 3.3.1 Monotony
sections.text: Inspired by what has been done in the field of non-monotonous reasoning, we define a property of monotony if these arguments are accepted before changes are accepted. Since our goal is to define general properties, we do not make assumptions about the number of extensions, and we have to consider various cases for the acceptance of an argument (gullible or skeptical accepted). A monotony definition is simple under a semantic that only provides for an extension (such as grounded semantics). Following definition 6, an argument A is accepted (gullible or skeptical accepted) in < A, R > iff it belongs to the (unique) extension of G. In this particular case, monotony means that the extension of G is included. If there are multiple extensions, monotony can take different forms. A gullible form corresponds to the case in which each argument is creatively accepted by G.

In fact, the addition of an argument that can interact with existing semantics is a very common type of change in real situations. Moreover, this type of change is sufficiently complex to provide a comprehensive analysis of properties and outcomes. We chose these two semantics because they are the most well-known traditional semantics for which the existence of extensions is guaranteed. Our goal is to determine conditions under which a given property will be satisfied for a change operation. Argumentation is basically concerned with the exchange of interacting arguments. This set of arguments may come either from a dialogue between several agents but also from the available (and possibly contradictory) pieces of information at the disposal of one unique agent. Usually, the interaction between arguments takes the form of a conflict, called attack. For example, a logical argument can be a pair 〈set of assumptions, conclusion〉, where the set of assumptions entails the conclusion according to some logical inference schema. A conflict occurs, for instance, when the conclusion of an argument contradicts an assumption of another argument. The main issue for any argumentation system is the selection of acceptable sets of arguments, called “extensions”, based on the way arguments interact (intuitively, an acceptable set of arguments must be in some sense coherent and strong enough, e.g., able to defend itself against all attacking arguments). So, the outcome of an argumentation system is often defined by the set of its extensions but, depending on the applications, it may be also defined as the set of arguments that belongs to every extension. Basic Concepts in Argumentation Frameworks The present work lies in the frame of the general theory of abstract argumentation frameworks proposed by Dung (1995). Such an abstract framework assumes that a set of arguments is given, as well as the different conflicts between them, and focuses on the definition of the status of arguments.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we address the problem of change in an abstract argumentation system. We focus on a particular change: the addition of a new argument which interacts with previous arguments. We study the impact of such an addition on the outcome of the argumentation system, more particularly on the set of its extensions. Several properties for this change operation are defined by comparing the new set of extensions to the initial one, these properties are called “structural” when the comparisons are based on set-cardinality or setinclusion relations. Several other properties are proposed where comparisons are based on the status of some particular arguments: the accepted arguments; these properties refer to the “evolution of this status” during the change, e.g., Monotony and Priority to Recency. All these properties may be more or less desirable according to specific applications. They are studied under two particular semantics: the grounded and preferred semantics.
